{{quote|This thing all things devours;
Birds, beasts, trees, flowers;
Gnaws iron, bites steel;
Grinds hard stones to meal;
Slays king, ruins town,
And beats mountain down.|Gollum's riddle{{H|Riddles}}}} '''Time''' is the life of [[Eä]].{{MR|P2j}} The [[Timeless Halls]] and the [[Void]] are implied to be outside Time. The Time began with Eä and the [[Valar]] descending to [[Arda]].{{S|Ainu}} Time perhaps represents the sequence of the chords sung by [[Eru]] in the [[Ainulindalë]].{{HM|Guide}}, entry "Time" The '''Count of Time''' begun with the first blooming of the [[Two Trees of Valinor]] at the [[Opening Hour]] (see further: ''[[Years of the Trees]]'').{{S|1}} The expression '''Deeps of Time''' probably loosely refers to the vast extent of Time{{HM|Guide}}, entry "Deeps of Time" in the unfathomable past or future, and each specific point is an immeasurable space in the Deeps of Time. ==Other versions of the legendarium== In an excerpt related to ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]'', Tolkien introduced some [[Ainur]] who represented the concept of time, and presented themselves to [[Manwë]]: '''[[Aluin]]''' was the eldest of the Ainur and represented Time itself, and his children were [[Fanuin]] (year), [[Ranuin]] (month) and [[Danuin]] (day).{{LT1|IX}}, p. 219 The excerpt however was soon rejected and the concept was not developed. While writing drafts of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', Tolkien considered that Time is [[magic]]ally "frozen", or passes in a different pace in [[Lothlórien]] , and the calendar didn't advance while the [[Company of the Ring]] was staying there; however he changed his mind later,{{HM|RC}}, pp. xxiv, xlvi, xlvii with the characters just losing some sense of time, which continued to flow normally.{{FR|River}} {{references}} [[Category:Time]]
